'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is concerned with how one ought to live. Morality is also described as the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are interpreted to be either "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or [[wrong]]). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.)consisting of absolute rules that cannot be broken. A ''moral'' is a lesson or teaching that places moral decisions within context. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness" although the common usage of the term in such a context assumes that any morality is good or right, but morality, or how one ought to live, is up to individual choices. Arguably personal definitions of "good" and "bad," are arbitrary, subjective, constrained by time, influenced by self-interest and rationalization, and widely varied.

'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or [[wrong]]). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. opposition to that which is good or right), while ''[[amorality]]'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>

''Immorality'' is the perception by one's self or other people that one lacks morality, based on their own conception of morality, and so is a criticism that is arguably mere disapproval, a label. Immorality is not the intentional opposition to that which is considered good or right, a claim that assumes that people choose to be immoral for the sake of disregarding morality, merely for the sake of it, when their actions may simply be based on necessity, history, habit, environment.

Simply believing that one is doing good for another because they are acting how they would like to be treated themselves, does not make it a moral act. This ignores the fact that personal likes/dislikes imposed on others is not a good deed if they are unwelcome. This "doing unto" may be an unwelcome imposition, when considering that some people may want to be left alone. Some people may want to left alone or have bizarre tastes. By not doing bad unto others, one decreases the possibility of undesirable consequences returned on them, such as retaliation, social ostracism.
  −   −
"Do unto others as you would have them do to you," is the same as "do good to receive good." When stated conversely, the message is "Do not do bad or misdeeds unto others in order to avoid retaliation." This is not a moral code, but a rule of self-interest. However, "love your neighbor as yourself" could be considered a moral guideline, but no more profound than "be kind" or "mean people suck."
